title: NWSL loses another legend as Christine Sinclair retires . Plus , can anyone stop Orlando ?

Another Goodbye
Sinclair announces NWSL retirement
The word demure had its moment, but semantic satiation has settled in. And the only athlete who could remind us of the true meaning is now leaving the game. You will not find a more modest or mindful international talent than all-time leading goal scorer Christine Sinclair, who‚Äôs drawing the curtain on her club career (she had already ended her international duties).
The 41-year-old has spent much of her career quietly breaking records, winning medals and putting Canada women‚Äôs soccer on the map.
She has more international goals than anyone, and yet when the red light goes on, you‚Äôll be hard-pressed to find her. She has been with the Portland Thorns since the start of NWSL, and her final game will be Nov. 1 at Providence Park in the regular-season finale against Angel City FC.
Sinclair‚Äôs subtle reign
Since we are more likely to get Sinc to talk about Pomeranians than her own career, we asked our de facto Sinclair historian, Steph, to share a few words:
‚ÄúMy first memory of Sinclair is a fuzzy one ‚Äî Canada played Japan at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass., during the 2003 Women‚Äôs World Cup and a much younger me had scrounged tickets and overcome mild travel anxiety to take the commuter rail out there for the first time. A 20-year-old Sinclair scored the go-ahead goal early in the first half. Little did I know that for the next 21 years, I would be following Sinclair‚Äôs every move.
It was a lot harder in the aughts to remotely follow women‚Äôs soccer, especially with the collapse of WUSA, so the journey of following Sinclair‚Äôs career has also been one in watching WoSo grow. I was amazed by the low-res streaming we got out of the 2008 Olympics, shocked by the comparative glitz of the 2011 World Cup and delighted to interact directly with players in WPS through Twitter. The goals I watched Sinclair score went from fuzzy blobs to crisp (sometimes) hi-def. And here we are in the futuristic year 2024 talking about what heights NWSL could reach when it gets to renegotiate its $240 million broadcast deal. It will be strange to move on to a world without Sinclair, but what a world she helped build.‚Äù

Sinclair joins Alex Morgan, Kelley O‚ÄôHara and Germany captain Alexandra Popp as international heroes who recently announced an end. Meanwhile, in Orlando, Marta isn‚Äôt ready to hang up her purple jersey just yet, despite calling an end to her international career earlier this year. Speaking of the Pride ‚Ä¶
NWSL Shield Race: Can anyone stop Orlando?
Despite having Marta and a rotating cast of supplemental stars, Orlando has made the postseason just once since debuting in 2016. This season, however, will forever change expectations of what this club can achieve.
- 2024 playoff spot ‚úÖ
- NWSL Shield and the league‚Äôs points record ‚è≥
The North Carolina Courage holds the league‚Äôs points record, earning 57 from 24 games in the 2018 season. Through 22 games, the Pride are on 54 points, and there‚Äôs little reason to think they can‚Äôt take four points or more from their next two games (home against Washington Spirit, before visiting the faltering Thorns).
Orlando can‚Äôt stop winning and is four games away from completing an undefeated season. But don‚Äôt let that outshine a strong wave of contenders.
It‚Äôs hard to see a weak spot among the top four. Ahead of an expanded postseason where eight teams qualify instead of six, we have a group that are a clear cut above the rest. ‚Äî Jeff Rueter
Meg‚Äôs Corner: Katie Meyer‚Äôs Law and her lasting legacy
California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed AB1575 into law this week, but its more common name, Katie Meyer‚Äôs Law, holds a deeper meaning.
There‚Äôs a clear memory of that December 2019 night during the College Cup in San Jose. Locked in penalty kicks against UNC, Stanford goalkeeper Katie Meyer captured a moment in the world of women‚Äôs soccer thanks to her skills, personality and an ESPN camera behind the goal.
Meyer took full advantage, shrugging and giving a begrudging nod of respect when she couldn‚Äôt save a penalty and providing an iconic ‚Äúzip your mouth‚Äù celebration when she could. The Cardinal won the championship.

Four years later, Sophia Smith did that same celebration after scoring a World Cup goal in memory of Meyer, her friend and Stanford teammate, who died by suicide in 2022. ‚ÄúEverything that we do is now for Katie,‚Äù Smith said that summer.
Fellow former Cardinal Naomi Girma has led on mental health in her off-the-field endeavors, including a retreat last offseason for players from all NWSL clubs called Create the Space, which she said was ‚Äúborn out of the extraordinary love and extraordinary grief for my best friend and teammate, Katie Meyer.‚Äù
Meyer‚Äôs parents, Gina and Steve, started Katie‚Äôs Save in her memory. And on Saturday, their work resulted in Newsom signing Katie Meyer‚Äôs Law, legislation that will provide students with an adviser of their choosing during disciplinary proceedings at California colleges and universities.
It‚Äôs another example of how Meyer‚Äôs legacy will live on, beyond the memories of her parents, teammates and friends, World Cup celebrations and GIFs of her own in 2019, and mental health work.
Notables
Chawinga shines again in game of the week
At first, the Kansas City Current-Gotham FC game was all about referee Katja Koroleva. This weekend, Koroleva and Kansas City attacker Michelle Cooper collided as Cooper chased down a loose ball. Gotham was able to recycle the attack and Yazmeen Ryan picked up a nice bounce off Alana Cook to force an own goal. While the KC fans felt hard done by, Koroleva‚Äôs answer to pool reporter Daniel Sperry was correct: The Laws of the Game do not call for a stoppage for player-ref collisions. And in the end, Temwa Chawinga made it all about her once again in the best possible way.
There‚Äôs no way to capture the epicness of Chawinga‚Äôs extensive run out from the center circle to her league-leading 17th goal of the season. You just need to go watch the highlight if you didn‚Äôt see it in real time (and full credit to Nealy Martin for trying to keep up, too). Chawinga is now one off Sam Kerr‚Äôs single-season goalscoring record and provided yet another compelling reason why she‚Äôs a legit MVP candidate and not just padding her Golden Boot lead.
Emma Hayes goes on tour
USWNT coach Emma Hayes is back in the U.S. after leading the team to a gold medal at the Paris Olympics. After a quick stop at MetLife Stadium to take in ‚ÄúThursday Night Football‚Äù (American version), Hayes made her way to the Windy City to watch the Chicago Red Stars host the Courage.

If she was scouting options for October camp, Hayes didn‚Äôt have to look much further than Ashley Sanchez. The North Carolina midfielder, who joined the league in 2020 after leaving UCLA early, recently became the first player to score against all 14 active NWSL teams. On Sunday, she set up Denise O‚ÄôSullivan‚Äôs goal in the 3-1 win with a cheeky backheel dribble.

Drawing it up: The 2024-25 UEFA Women‚Äôs Champions League groups are set. The group stage gets underway Oct. 8 and includes the return of Manchester City after a four-year hiatus from the European competition. There‚Äôs also already a scheduling issue for English teams.
